Hi,
	Interesting paper, sorry for the long delay.

	I'm very interested in this area but I have a few questions about why you 
chose the exact approach that you did.  When I first read the title, I 
imagined a slightly different approach.  You might call what I imagined the 
"omnipresent eye" [OE] in contrast to the actual roving eye [RE] approach....

	An OE approach would consist of iterating a single network over every 
possible position (and orientation and mirroring) on the board, recording a 
single output.  Then playing at the position where the output was highest.

	This has a weakness of locality (it cannot bring data from further afield 
than the radius of the eye) but the strength that it will consider every 
location on the board in every turn (and, for efficiency,  you can cache 
values for positions where no new stones were placed since the last turn).

	However, I don't believe in the paper you documented any measurements of 
how much information was carried over from one eye position to the next?

<<Interesting side-note _is_ there any mathematical theory which would give 
us such a measure, e.g. if we populate an eye's inputs at one board 
position, we can suppose that all nodes which the evaluation wave has 
reached are 100% filled with data from this position.  If we move the eye 
to another position and run another update, is there some maths we can do 
with the weights to tell us what proportion of the data in each node came 
from this position and how much is left form the last.  Obviously this can 
only apply where there is recurrence.  My first thought is just to 
calculate it as if the data was solutions mixing, thus you'd just multiply 
the current "concentration" of data from each source by the connection 
weightings and renormalise to keep the overall "quantity" of data 
constant.  This would allow contributions to decay to less than 1 bit but...>>

	Ian Badcoe
